profileText: (Uncle of Edmund Jenings Randolph), a Delegate from Virginia; born at Tazewell Hall, Williamsburg, Va., in September 1721; received his early education under private tutors; attended the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va., c. 1739; studied law at the Middle Temple, London, England; was appointed King's attorney for Virginia in 1744 and served until 1754; member of the Virginia House of Burgesses, 1748-1775, and served as speaker from 1766-1775; chairman of the committee of correspondence in 1773; president of the Virginia conventions of 1774 and 1775; Member of the Continental Congress in Philadelphia, Pa., September 5, 1774, and elected its President but resigned October 22, 1774, to attend the Virginia House of Burgesses; reelected to the Continental Congress, which met in Philadelphia in May 1775 and again served as President; died in Philadelphia, Pa., October 22, 1775; interment beneath the chapel of the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va.
